bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the original.

div1.p:
Edward Gantt vs. Thomas Baldwin ST. LOUIS CIRCUIT COURT.
Take notice that on the 24th day of November in the year of our Lord on thousand eight hundred and thirty-six, between the hours of eight in the forenoon and five in the afternoon, of that day, at the office of David Hough in the City of St. Louis depositions will be taken by the undersigned, to be read on the trial of the above entitled case, on behalf of the defendant; and that the taking of said depositions, if not completed on that day, will be continued from dat to day at the same place and between the same hours, until completed. To the above named plantiff & Allen & Gamble his attys. 19 Novr. 1836 Thomas Baldwin

Gantt vs. Baldwin notice
County of St. Louis ss; Peter Brown being sworn says that he gave a true copy of written notice to messrs Allen & Gamble attorneys at St. Louis on this 19th November 1836 sworn to & subsribed before me this 19 Nov. 1836 D. Hough, P G Burns

State of Missouri County Saint Louis ss Deposition of a witness produced sowrn and examined the twenty fourth day of November eighteen hundred and thirty six, between the hours of eight in the afternoon and five in the afternoon of said day, in pursuance of the notice hereto announced before me D Hough a justice of the peace within and for the County aforesaid , at my office in the City of Saint Louis, in a certain cause now pending in the Circuit Court of Saint Louis County between Edward Gantt plaintiff and Thomas Baldwin defedent on behalf of the defendant
John Burt being produced sowrn and examined deposith and saith that he went on board the Steam Boat Tempest as clerk in September 1835 and remained on board after as clerk till the ensuing April, and then as capitain till August 1836 _ the said Boat was at St. Louis on the 24th November 1835 _ an attempt was made to go up to Quincy, but ran up 3 or 4 miles above Alton and was prevented ascending higher on account of it.
and then returend to St. Louis _ and again attempted to go up, and decided in going a little higher than the first time, but fund the river forger over and finally returned again to St. Louis _ and then the said Boat started for Louisville somewhere toward the 10th dec - 1835 the exact day not recollected _ The Lady Jackson Stean Boat started from St. Louis for Louisville down the river the day before the Tempest did, and on the voyage the Tempest overtook her about too quickly below St. Louis, and to ask her passengers who were bound for Louisvile _ The Steam Boat Indian left St. Louis for Louisville on the same day the Tempest did perhaps about 4 or 5 hours before the Tempest left, and about 9 Oclock in the morning _ the Tempest left about 12 or 1 - The Tempest overtook the Indian also and took his passengers -
